content.user_title: Model AI Agent Mental States with BDI Ontology
content.value_statement: Transform RDF data into cognitive agent architectures using formal Belief-Desire-Intention patterns. Enable AI systems to model rational agency with traceable reasoning chains and semantic interoperability.
actual_capabilities: Provides BDI ontology patterns for belief-desire-intention modeling
Includes RDF/Turtle examples for mental state representation
Offers SPARQL queries for competency validation
Documents integration patterns for SEMAS and JADE frameworks
Contains temporal reasoning patterns for mental state evolution
limitations: Documentation only - no executable implementation provided
Requires external RDF/SPARQL tools for actual processing
Ontology examples need adaptation for specific domains

prompt_templates.title: Basic BDI Modeling
prompt_templates.scenario: Transform simple scenarios into BDI mental states
prompt_templates.prompt: Given this scenario: [describe situation], create RDF triples representing the agent's beliefs, desires, and intentions using BDI ontology patterns

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Agent Coordination
prompt_templates.scenario: Model shared beliefs across multiple agents
prompt_templates.prompt: Design BDI mental states for agents that need to coordinate on [task]. Include shared beliefs and complementary intentions

prompt_templates.title: Temporal Reasoning
prompt_templates.scenario: Track mental state evolution over time
prompt_templates.prompt: Create BDI mental states that change over time for this sequence: [timeline]. Include validity intervals and process triggers

prompt_templates.title: Conflict Resolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Given conflicting beliefs [list beliefs] and intentions [list intentions], model the resolution process using BDI justification patterns

output_examples.input: An agent perceives heavy traffic on their commute route and needs to decide on alternative transportation
output: Belief: 'Route 101 has heavy traffic with 30-minute delay' (references world state, justified by traffic data)
Desire: 'Arrive at work on time' (motivated by traffic belief)
Intention: 'Take alternate route via Highway 280' (fulfills desire, supported by traffic belief)
Plan: Sequence of tasks [exit Route 101, merge onto 280, navigate to destination]

best_practices: Always link mental states to world states via refersTo relationships for grounding
Include temporal validity intervals for all mental entities to support diachronic reasoning
Use bidirectional properties (motivates/isMotivatedBy) for flexible querying
Provide explicit justifications for each mental state to enable explainability
anti_patterns: Conflating mental states with world states - beliefs reference but are not world states
Missing temporal bounds - every mental state needs validity intervals
Flat belief structures - use compositional modeling with hasPart for complex beliefs
Direct intention-to-action mapping - intentions specify plans which contain tasks

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with existing BDI frameworks?
faq.answer: Yes, it provides integration patterns for SEMAS, JADE/JADEX, and other BDI platforms through ontology mapping

faq.question: What are the limitations of the BDI approach?
faq.answer: BDI models require explicit representation of all mental states and may not capture subconscious or emotional factors

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my existing RDF data?
faq.answer: Use the T2B2T pattern: translate your RDF to beliefs, apply BDI reasoning, then project back to RDF

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this ontology?
faq.answer: This is documentation only - no data processing occurs. Implementations should validate RDF inputs and use secure SPARQL endpoints

faq.question: How do I handle inconsistent mental states?
faq.answer: Use justification tracking to identify conflicts, then apply resolution strategies like temporal partitioning or belief revision

faq.question: How does this compare to other cognitive architectures?
faq.answer: BDI focuses on practical reasoning with clear mental state distinctions, making it more interpretable than neural approaches
